Kot3FsjHRsoy_2k5IVROgw.text: No frills place with a huge menu with pictures - a large selection of rolls, nigiri, sashimi, cooked food and noodles. We ordered the gyoza, a couple of rolls, a chirashi bowl and some nigiri. Everything was pretty good, but nothing outstanding. The perfect definition of Yelp's 3 stars: A-OK.

qjSNw9nVKJYH5Fhf-s18FA.text: Eat Tokyo is classic, if I need a quality and affordable Japanese food then this is the place to be. This place will feed the biggest eaters or a hungry stomach. The Soho branch is larger than some of their other branches. May be its new so the deco is nicer. It is definitely in a better location than their previous Soho branch.Being popular it is busy and you will often see a queue outside the street. The staff will try their best to turn the tables politely so don't always expect to be staying around for a drinkd after you have finished your food.The best about Eat Tokyo is the selection on the menu including the hot food. I love their Bento boxes that suit a peckish person like me who wants a bit of sushi, a bit of rice, a bit of salad and a bit of fish or meat.Being Japanese you can not forget about sushi. There is various of selection from the basic to the more creative. If you have a large group or special occassion then their sushi boat is magnificent to have on the table. One of my favourite has to be the dragon rolls and although I have seen other places that does smiliar rolls, it is not as good as Eat Tokyo.It always a good casual Japanese place apart from the queue to get a table so don't recommend coming in a large group. But if its for two to four people I have never found that I needed to wait too long at this branch.

hNSTxWvtu2-ms-XpqWSY_w.text: Right, it was the second time I ate at Eat Tokyo (after the great first time at Holborn one). I ordered the same dish, which was the Chirashi Don (cos' I couldn't stop thinking about it after the first time). My friend went there to queue, they wouldn't let her in before everybody showed up, but luckily we didn't have to wait for long. This one in Soho is new, that was why the decor was better/newer. The food came quite quickly comparing to last time in Holborn. The Chirashi Don was a bit different. Unfortunately, it wasn't as good. The sushi rice was a bit hard/raw, fish was so tough and the squid was like a piece of rubber, I just gave up at the end. I guess it was just bad luck, as my friends's dishes were delicious.

h_Gw8MK1edHaaT3pcx0gSQ.text: Some of the best Sashimi in London and I've been searching! Fantastically attentive and enthusiastic waitstaff. The portions are generous for the price. The flavours are fresh and authentic. The line outside is full of people in the know and what is on offer is definitely worth the wait.

H3HcK3h0e28tV73ONw73Ug.text: Eat Tokyo is a great place to go for a quick meal! Its buzzing,there are always long queues outside and we were lucky to get a table for two just in time before everyone else arrives (Saturday at 5:30pm).Service wasnt the friendliest, but fast and helpful! We tried a selection of different sushi rolls which were all delicious and one of the Bento boxes. Good quality food for a good price! I cant wait to visit again!

QPCT5XsaMmyWJHh_GDN3sQ.text: Busy place. Not sure if any of the employees were Japanese, perhaps the sushi chefs. The menu is huge. It is almost a book. Too big of a menu means normally average food. I ordered the chicken tonkatsu double size. The plate is huge you get twice as much rice, potato and sauce. Presentation is ok. You get a lot of good for 9£ but the taste is average. Nonetheless I still give it 4 stars for very reasonable prices in a expensive neighborhood. My advice: kick out 50% of the menu and focus and less but better tasting dishes.

Kv-2GEki2CpOJpTQnO-MkQ.text: Best Japanese restaurant ! Fresh seafood / amazing bento , extensive menu, and friendly staff

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Lunch time bento

2TxpmD2lCGJwIKavBuISWQ.text: Bad! Food poisoning bad.... Came here after a few good reviews and am very disappointed and sick ... ordered bento box with salmon/tuna sashimi and now i am not in a good state. Never again

wfmIMndiS9J0WzAE-H6IJQ.text: There is no doubt that the food here is awesome and deserves the money you pay. Sometimes you must be careful when you order as the portion of the bento can be very big. The food here is authentic but the reason I give it 4 stars is because service is also part of Japanese culture, as a big Japanese restaurant chain in London, apparently they still need pay lots of efforts to improve their quality of service.

KqYT9lrfsbF9We8Kb9G-tA.text: It's my first time coming here. We ordered different dishes instead of bento boxes. The delivery was really slow. We were almost full when several dishes still weren't delivered to us. The sushi here was not bad. The Crab Sake was too salty. Most ironically, my friend ordered Udon with with tempura and they are delivered more than half an hour apart. When we asked one of the waitress if she could check with the kitchen to deliver the rest of the dishes we have prefer. She was really rude and didn't want to explain to us and just shoved the order to another server. There were just too many thing that I could complain about. This is probably a good place to come seems the bento boxes have large portions. But others dishes were pretty mediocre. In a word, I don't want to ever come back to this place ever again.

8rmJyOeIIxcSacNcXvw6CQ.text: Followed the reviews on here. Nothing special. Food ok, service ok. There's a big queue and wait but nothing special.

YPd98y_xEAnM4DsannoXfw.text: The new Eat Tokyo in Old Compton street is everything one expects from this chain and then some. Good prices for delicious, nicely portioned AND great quality dishes! It's got a great variety of them too! And the menu has got pictures of everything, so you can get a feel of a dish you've never tried before, so you don't have to go in completely blind. The atmosphere is bright and relaxed, and the added space means the waiting queues have become shorter. Also, great service, quite fast, despite how busy the place always is! All in all, a highly recommended restaurant for anyone who enjoys good Japanese food!

qvsVSQXedfqrA7JWwwi49Q.text: New Eat Tokyo around SOHO. The location is better than the old one I think. The restaurant is way bigger as well so there is a lot more space. Food is always good and the price is reasonable. However I think they are short of hands right now service is poor.

u3O8thZIiCx3BtlNQXJswQ.text: The service is absolutely terrible!!! We've come to London twice this year and both times we've come here..the staff has forgotten to bring out one of our two main entrées. Then when you inquire where the other entrée is, all you receive is a half-assed excuse!!! But fear not, your second entrée will magically appear as soon as you ask for your check...an HOUR later! Gave them the benefit of the doubt last time we were here...but now I can honestly say the service here is utter crap!

qeN5th4qP7hdLJ_pi9MrEA.text: Excellent Japanese restaurant just in the center of Soho.Fresh, nicely served Japanese food at affordable prices. The service could have been better but you will love the whole experience. Be prepared for long queues during peak hours. Totally recommended - Arigato!

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Eat Tokyo

BFS8vHaGhGcnPbfdn6ouoA.text: Eat Tokyo is always a safe choice for reasonably priced standard Japanese affair. Although the Soho branch is usually the one I tend to avoid in the weekends being always busy, slow in service and very loud. Over the years it has became so popular that it kind of has lost it's Japanese feel to it. Staff are mostly Chinese who cannot speak good English and the place seems to fail at keeping clean, especially the toilet which is disguising with it's poor water pressure to flush properly. Still, decor remains authentic to the traditional Japanese culture with it's wooden decor. It is a big restaurant too, with separate rooms to drown out some sound and we were placed in one of those rooms, sharing it with other diners. Service was a mix and match. Some staff seems to be affected by the stressful atmosphere showing signs of frustration and unhappiness. However we were fortunate to be given a more relaxed and friendly staff who looked after us well and came back to make sure our food was okay.Yasai itameMainly Chinese leaves, beansprouts and the occasional carrot, generously portioned and stir fried well with garlic, salt and pepper. Seasoning was spot on allowing the sweet flavours of the vegetables to come through. A bit oily which can be seen by how shiny it was. Age-gyoza Being deep fried, it produced a really crispy skin surrounding the outside yet a lovely chewier texture as you continue to chew on it. It was satisfying and a lovely filling of pork that was flavoured nicely with the accompanied diced greens inside.Takoyaki These were nice and plump although the perfect golden crust around it may suggest that they were pre made and then deep fried again to reheat them. Nevertheless the ratio of dough and octopus inside was good, crispy on the outside whilst soft and doughy on the inside. The octopus was nice and tender, all flavoured nicely with bonito flakes for an extra depth of seafood flavour and mayonnaise for a creamy finishUnagi avocado rollNicely assembled using good quality ingredients that gave out satisfying flavours and texture. It had a lovely sweet savoury note, a tender buttery texture which was accentuated by the soft avocado. Garnished with black sesame seeds to give it a smokey nutty finish.Alaskan roll This was more moist and softer in texture filled with a nice oily salmon piece and a juicy bit of prawn. The tobiko surrounding the roll gave burst of saltiness as well as a richer depth of flavour.Pork cutlet curryWe ordered a large and it could have probably feed four. Beautifully panko fried pork, crispy and golden brown revealing a lovely juicy tender pork cutlet inside. Curry sauce was generous along with the fluffy potatoes and soften carrots. It has all the nice savoury and sweet notes we're used to and enough of it to mix in with the rice given.Oyako jyuThis has never failed me. The chicken is always cut into big chunks to keep it moist and tender, always the thigh too which my favourite part. All cooked with lovely caramelised onions in a lovely sweet soy, mirin and dashi sauce before pouring a beaten egg to give it a velvety creamy texture.Buta kakuni This was the only disappointing dish of the day being very tough, stringy and dense. You can say it wasn't fatty enough so the meat didn't marbleised. The soy marinate was nice just shame about the meat itselfSapporo RamenGenuinely surprised with how good the ramen was. Described as miso soup ramen it had depth and umami from the underlying chicken broth which also gave it the sweet flavour. Greater depth of flavour was achieved by the toppings of fatty tender pork belly, sweetcorn, bamboo shoots, wood ear fungus and garnishes of spring onion. Sadly the egg was not the soft boiled ones you usually get. Noodles were from a high quality supplier though being fresh and bouncy.I do love Eat Tokyo but sadly the atmosphere and hygiene lets it down and so for that it loses 2 stars. Depending on where you are you might not be able to hear the person next you due to the high noise level. Only use the toilet if you have to as it says toilet paper should not be flushed so you see all sorts in the bin next to you. Half the time it is blocked anyway for those who do not follow. But it is a great place to organise a large group meeting as large portion sizes caters for sharing and lots of small dishes too. Prices are pretty decent too. I would recommend to make a reservation on the weekend or turn up early as it can get really busy and you might have to queue.

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Buta kakuni
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Unagi avocado roll and Alaskan roll
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Sapporo Ramen

9qt_PfgtCPi-oPmkl9JISg.text: There always seems to be a queue for this branch of  Eat Tokyo and whilst it's portions are big and value for money, I wouldn't queue more than 15min for it. It's rather mediocre and it's quantity over quality. The sashimi platter on the boat is good value but again it's nothing special. There is however a good selection of starters, from fried food, salads, sushi and grilled meats. The main has wide selection as well from rice, noodle dishes, bento boxes for those who want more of a variety and tempura. Verdict is to go if you're super hungry and looking for something cheap. It's not a date spot or for foodies.

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom

Nr3_XzJ-YEDgM3yinDiD4w.text: The food here is very good and the price is not too bad, most of the staff are nice.I always have the chicken teriyaki bento box and for 8.50 it's a bargain.I would highly recommend, even if there is a queue it's fast moving and we'll worth the wait.

2wNcFvxfWSbfYCBwt2vFXA.text: Not sure the hype. After waiting 45 min outside in rain, once inside the restaurant is  1/2 full. Ok it's  probably the least expensive of all sushi restaurants in London however not the freshest either. I ordered medium toro and it was clearly frozen. The owner immediately took it back and kindly offered for other sashimi. All in all- ther are 100's sushi places, wouldn't  recommend to eat here, not worth the wait.

pngKjCldxfrxXSOkd1o6vA.text: Expect a wait during dinner hours but we were seated quickly within 20 minutes for a table of two. The restaurant's atmosphere was bustling and waiters really don't have the time to serve your every need so be prepared to just ask for what you want. You'll get amazing Japanese food for the price, especially for Soho in London. Definitely worth the portion and value. Their extensive menu can be overwhelming but their chef's special rolls are worth a try. I would also recommend the udon as the broth is incredibly flavourful.

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom

keFYC6HFk4HPRyDu0F5uRw.text: For Saturday nights, I often can't imagine going out to dinner without a reservation, let alone in Soho. But my friend suggested this place, promised the queue moves fast, and despite arriving at prime dinner time around 7:45 PM, we were seated within half an hour. I think you can book a table as well, but it wasn't like a reservations mandatory type of place, and the tables turned around surprisingly fast. There is also a little stand outside with a book of authentic Japanese restaurants in London, and of course Eat Tokyo's locations are recommended in the book. It's funny that such a book exists, but Japanese cuisine has become so mainstream that it is refreshing to come to a more low key, almost hole-in-the-wall place like this.The menu is a little overwhelming; it is basically a book of laminated pages with pictures. And there is so much choice. A bento ranges from 10-15 pounds, but there are also endless options of sushi rolls, ramen, and appetizers. We ordered a sushi roll, edamame beans, and gyoza for the table, and then the others each got a bento / ramen and I got a eel and ikura hand roll, fried oysters, and black cod with miso. I enjoyed everything, but I must say, the fried oysters impressed me because it was an extremely generous portion with 5 large oysters served with salad. The others struggled to finish their meal and a lot of rice was left over at the end, but we all left very full and content. For all that, including three pints of beer and a tea, and tip, it was only 25 pounds a person - what a bargain!

6uc2Q3NFJ8sIU1uKHVqoxg.text: 3.5 stars. If you want actual authentic Japanese food, then this is probably not the best place to go... Well I've only tried the Gyudon here, gotta say I was slightly disappointed. It wasn't bad, but it was pretty much just beef on top of plain rice, well you can argue that's what Gyudon is about, but this ones just lacking some flavour and it was pretty dry that I had to pour my miso soup into it lol. But on the plus side, the portion of beef was good, and the beef tasted nice, to be fair. One other thing though, I found the pricing kinda strange, slightly random. some dishes were really cheap while some others were quite expensive? (As in compared to the same dishes in other restaurants)

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Gyudon (beef bowl)

14DyvgetvJurQAXoNR_S5g.text: Very japanese, full of japanese also inside, lot of choice and price quite good. Bento box its a good mix to try different things

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Chicken bento box 8

DXifOdqn9Bd9A7Sc3YIHCA.text: This is my first time going to an Eat Tokyo branch that's not been Holborn but I had originally been to this chain many times before and the food has always been excellent. So far, I would like to say that this branch was better than Holborn in every respect in terms of food, atmosphere and definitely staff friendliness. The main waiter who served us was someone I knew previously at Holborn Eat Tokyo, Kim, but as I understand it, he's mainly based at Old Compton. I only saw Kim once at Holborn at that experience was much better than the others at that particular branch.Kim even remembered us from before which we were all delighted about as we spoke very highly of him last time. You'll be very lucky if you have him serve you as he's always very funny and very helpful with recommending such orders to you. As an additional bonus point, he even sang the birthday song with us for one of my friend's birthday which I should commend him for great singing. Eat Tokyo were able to accommodate a birthday cake and we were not rushed to eat our food at all - no set time limit given to us even on a Saturday night unlike Holborn! The food was delicious as always - I, whilst opting for a more Chinese-styled dinner (I don't eat seafood so I was stuck for choices but that's my own problem, not the restaurant) rather than authentic Japanese, still thought the food was an amazing. I ordered chili egg plant, mince pork and rice (Mabo-nasu), a great option if you like spicy food and have seafood allergies. The spice was excellent but not enough even if I had asked for extra chilli - that's not their problem though because my chilli intake is very high. A friend of mine actually thought it was too much spice in contrast. Note that the additional chilli cost me £1.50. I also ordered 6 vegetable spring rolls (Harumaki) which was cheap at £2.50 - unfortunately, my friends were quick to help themselves that I didn't get a picture. These were crispy and just perfect, faultless. My friend's dishes were all delicious I am told - My only slight gripe was that the kitchen served a fish dish to one of my friends food when he asked for no-fish as he's a vegetarian. This was quickly resolved so no problems. I most definitely will be back again at the Compton branch and I think I'll pass on the Holborn one from now on where the service is not comparable even if the food is the same - I remember the last time I organized a birth cake cake at Holborn Eat Tokyo, one of the staff members actually brought out the cake in the bag and ruined the surprise, which annoyed me. Note that this is not a reflection on Kim as he wasn't there on that occasion. As always, I'll post up the photographs of the food that we enjoyed.

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Teriyaki Tuna Jyu
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Apologize for the not so great picture. This is Teriyaki Tuna Jyu
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom

uzt-u4R7wFKPhAxpK2a7Og.text: Wow, wow, wow! If you like sushi/sashimi don't miss this restaurant, everything is so fresh & tasty. Worth the wait. Staff very friendly & helpful.

GeQLXppDPPONXqONq2FckQ.text: This place is one of the more well known places for Japanese food along side Misato so expect to be queuing on the busier days like Saturday evening for instance. This branch was originally based in Whitcomb Street near Trafalgar Square which was a lot smaller than the new place.The menu has a wide range of choose from sushi, noodles, bento boxes and especially katsu curry which comes either in chicken or pork and also has a regular or large serving. The menus themselves have their old school binder look to them but are informative as they show a picture for most of the food they serve.For starters I had the Korokke which is a breaded potato croquette served with salad and a sauce on the side, which went great with them. For the main dish I had the Chicken Katsu Curry in the regular size and was surprised on how much was on the plate.Eat Tokyo prices are affordable for the most part with sushi rolls starting at £2 and thee regular size Katsu Curry being £7 and £9 for the large. So I recommended coming at off peak times to get the best service from them as when it's busy they can take some time to getting to your order and can get hectic as well.

4f3bRmboPqPjpdt_68xtxQ.text: I went back to Eat Tokyo for the first time since I went about a year ago. The location had changed to Soho with a larger space -- a much needed change since when I last went, we had to wait an hour just to get a table. Food was solid as always. I ordered udon and California rolls, both of which hit the spot for me. What I generally like about Eat Tokyo is their authenticity -- no bells and whistles, but simple and just as they would serve it in a Japanese household. All this for a reasonable price too. Service was prompt and good overall, though toward the end, I got the feeling that they were trying to rush us out so that they could serve new customers. Understandable, but not the best feeling. Would go back for a low key, quick Japanese fix.

668akDgi-_9UHNMgRxsyMA.text: With Eat Tokyo in Golders Green being one of my favorite places to go for japanese in Londo, I was excited to hear that they had opened up another location in Soho. Upon my first visit I was greeted by a small que, but it moved quickly and within 5 minutes we had seats by the bar, which is really great if you're only two people. While overseeing the jovial chefs at work, we dug into the hefty menu. At first the excessive amount of choices can seem a bit daunting, and also give you that sense of a Chinese-place-that-does-pizza-and-sushi-and-fish-and-chips-and-none-of-it-is-any-good, but the experience here is really quite the opposite. There is a lot to choose from, but it is all thing I long to see in any other Japanese restaurant. From pumpkin croquettes, to nasu dengaku, natto, some wonderfully crispy and flavoursome gyozas, and a healthy choice of sushi, sashimi and ramen, Eat Tokyo does most things pretty well, and some things better than most. As restaurants in Soho generally tend to up their prices in comparison to other affiliated locations, I was happy to see that here they are pretty much the same as in Golders Green. The staff are attentive and very friendly. The chefs even manage to say goodbye to you when you leave, despite the steady stream of orders and precision with which they make the food. When it comes to what to order I'd say try it all. This is a great place to go with a larger group and sample things you might not have had before while still getting something your familiar with. The bento boxes are great value, but maybe not that much of a thrill. It's better than Wasabi, but really, you get what you pay for. I love the different larger rolls that are perhaps not strictly authentic Japanese, but combined with the right starters will be a great eating experience. The one with avocado and eel is terrific! The Nasu Dengaku is a bit too sweet for my taste and works best if shared, as its richness will be a bit overpowering as a whole. This is definitely my go to space when I want to know what I'll get for a good price in the area. I'd also recommend you to go there even if it is slightly out of your way. I'd even say that this beats many of the fine dining Japanese options around, but that all depends on what you are after. You're not going to get an experience of complex and surprising flavours here, but you will get good quality food with a no fuss approach that still pays attention to detail. Now all I need to find is a decent Yakitori restaurant and my foundation of Japanese eating in London will be complete.

A6E5Bn3eb2dhE9UsnwyweA.text: Some of the best sushi I've had and a great value. This place is not cheap, but again a great value for what you get. Most of the tables I eyed coming in ordered the bento plates which looked phenomenal, I was with a large group so we ordered a variety f things for table and each one was better than the next.Tip: The place is in the heart of soho and is quite popular - book ahead or expect to queue.

BZTaZPP0JMWe9g0A43J3FA.text: Good value, ok food. If you are thinking of a authentic, exquisite Japanese dining experience, this place is not for you. However if you want Japanese curry or don in large portion, you are at the right place!

vvCbHO7PoKsLKQ5HdNrRRg.text: Eat Tokyo is a really nice, cosy restaurant. I've been only to their Soho branch and luckily, we came just before the queue started forming so I can't complain about that.Their sushi tastes fresh and there's a lot of it as well. Same with bento boxes. All of the food is reasonably priced as well. If I would have to point out two things that I liked the most though, it would be their miso soup (oh so comforting and delicious) and Japanese plum wine. Will come again soon when really hungry!

6vOAOKgMGMX-7lvzZ15kkg.text: Bah, don't bother to come here. Seriously, don't.It may have been my experience only, considering the rating gave by other people (no it's not, that's just something I say for politeness).Came here in a group of 6 people, rude attitude from the waiters (that's ok in a chinese restaurant, abysmail in a japanese one) at the entrance. Bad N*1Menu is 30 pages long maybe, dirty and in plastic folders. Seriously, it looked more like the notes that spread around a class at university rather than a list of dishes. Bad N*2Dishes and beverages arrived with 15 minutes of delay one by each other. Not the way you want to eat, staring at other people eating and then being watched while doing so. Bad N*3Food was very low quality at best. Tempura was greasy, oily and fatty, very low quality. Sushi was badly prepared, rice falling in pieces as it was too hot (and not just slightly above room temperature as it should be). Salmon was average quality, but tuna was really bad quality. Fresh, but low quality.Just don't come, if you want to eat sushi there are tons of places better than this one, if you want to eat katsu just go to Misato (compare my review there with this one please!)

ypJw6pTwKdXQ1M59SQ4gfQ.text: This is how I want to eat sushi - in a low key, authentic environment with great sushi chefs. There is no posturing bankers with their tipsy dates. There are no dress codes or door guys. There is no elevator to take you up, up, up to a view of London. There is no "fusion."There's just a really big menu, an efficient (if unpredictably friendly) staff and spot on price point for what you get.When we came on a Friday night I was thankful we had a reservation since the line was out the door (and kudos for even taking reservations for parties of 2 - not many Central London places do it for fewer than 6!). When I came for lunch I was thankful my 8 pieces of nagiri and glass of wine only came to £24. A place like Sushi Samba I would have gotten half that (and no drink).The menu IS overwhelming if you don't know what you want. There are bento boxes and chef's rolls and nagiri and ramen and lunch specials and curries and on and on ... It is also a messy presentation because the plastic sleeves which contain pages and pages of items (with photos) are in a school binder. There is no slick branding or carefully selected typeface. But it is damn good sushi. It is a place that offers something for everyone.

R1nZsz2ukzVBLTIaryFcaA.text: Food is good and inexpensive. I tried Salmon teriyaki, which was slightly fatty. Still good quality considering the price under 10 pounds. Worth trying!

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom

jDFY0GDehBqzT1czm3-Qig.text: Good some good sushi here. Happy that there was no wait, tempura and sashimi were really good. Service was efficient.

vLC0_WXw3cmFX54JOFgDoQ.text: Went to the ever-packed Eat Tokyo in Soho (booking in advance is a must unless you're into queuing outside - even on a Sunday night). I ordered the following:- Sea bream sashimi- Rainbow roll- Genkotsu-AgeThe sashimi is fairly standard as is the rainbow roll (an assortment of uramaki/nigiri style sushi made of different fish) which isn't a criticism. These tick the boxes for those times when you crave sushi but doesn't go much beyond. The genkotsu-age on the other hand is an interesting take on battered and fried chicken, for those like me who enjoy things like gristle and cartilage for the added crunch as these include soft and edible bone. Served with Japanese mayonnaise and a slice of lemon, I would highly recommend this as a side or even as a snack with a beer if popping in for a light meal.With a menu the size of a small encyclopaedia there are simply too many items that I haven't yet tried to give Eat Tokyo a fair rating but from a sushi point of view, you can find better elsewhere.

-0hjX_D87oowv7Rnpfn67Q.text: Nice address discovered thanks to my Japanese colleagues!Luckily, we made a reservation because this place is really popular and can get pretty crowded!We ordered different meals to share: maki roll, gyozas, Kimchi buta nikku, vegetables, karaage... Everything was good and authentic!Also, after that I ate a gyudon, amazing! It was not the same taste than in Japan but it was good.I recommend this place if you are looking for good, authentic and not too expensive Japanese food.

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Buta kimchi, edamame, shells,...
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Gyuudon

h3g96_T--j1uRiHk_HEVDA.text: We went there for Saturday lunch and ordered Tonkatsu set and Salmon/avocado Uramaki.  They had a weird seating system.  Although there were many empty seats inside, they told us to wait outside.  The serving staff did not possess the usual politeness you expect from a Japanese restaurant.  They were a bit surly, rushed and abrupt.  The diners were non-Japanese when we were there.We were very disappointed with the food except Tonkatsu.  Miso soup was very salty and contained tough age.  Agedashi Tofu was topped with shredded nori which gave the unpleasant flavour/taste, and the dashi was not flavourful; maybe nori killed it.  Tontkatsu itself was good but had burnt panko bits - sure sign of them not cleaning the oil properly.  Salad was pleasant and had good dressing.  Unfortunately the rice was mushy.  Sushi in the set was OK, but the rice on Uramaki was tough.This chain spread too fast, and is now lacking the important basic elements such as polite service and paying attention to details.  We hope they would improve these elements soon.

OHj0CDNf_8kNLxhGt3xwBw.text: The menu here is crazy huge but they also have a good value price.  Not too expensive and affordable for soho.  Come here early if you do not want to queue during peak hours.  Honestly, I had a hard time choosing the food here when they gave me the menu.  I think it was too big.  But the food that came out was perfect for its price and reflected in the quality.  Portion is huge as well.  Obviously, it is not michelin star quality, but the price caters for everyone.  I loved the eel with rice.  Do give this place a try.

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom

7iYRkoNqA3AnE8o1QPLJxA.text: I always come here. Great authentic Japanese food for an amazing price. Normally, I order the large chicken katsu curry , which is around £9. Literally bigger than an average persons head. I never finish it and always end up taking away the leftovers. The wait for a table is around 40mins but it's worth it. Staff are lovely and very attentive! The waiting in the line flys by if you are with a group of friends so it's not too bad. EAT Tokyo will always be my staple go to restaurant in London for Japanese cravings

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Sushi boat!!
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Chicken katsu curry is massive! 9 ~

ZzAzuyaYR-idO3fKSI7xDQ.text: Would have given five stars if had not been so busy but the food definitely deserved five stars. The only negative is that the food was not served at the same time, so my mum's food was slowly going cold as we waited for mine. I had dish B11 (bento 3) and got the best tempura I have ever eaten and delicious sashimi!

OYH8skFAR-HvWRdfSIpJUw.text: Excellent fresh food accompanied by excellent service. Keenly priced with a massive menu with each chef having their own section. A must try.

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom

mnNAC1NipnOQn6iUdtJZbg.text: Delicious food, fast service and nice staff. We had a very nice meal at Eat Tokyo before we went "next door" to see the musical Aladdin. Will definitely come back here lateron.

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom

SIRslkwxb0-C1sHkcGHaKQ.text: This place had cheap food that tasted 3 times it's value elsewhere. It's one of those gems that I feel bad exposing it to the world but I realise it's pretty popular in the Soho area anyways so it doesn't matter. Bento boxes are a must-try and so is their whole crab (which cost only £7)!!! Had a wonderful experience with the food coupled with some funny posters I saw in the loos!However, this place was packed before and after we finished dining and servers kept coming to our table to check if they could take our empty plates away as a strategy to free up the table as quickly as possible. But servers were polite in times of rush so props to them

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Our meal!
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Spicy crab that was meaty and well flavoured though it could be spicier to get the tastebuds really tingling
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom. Eel bento taste just like the ones from Japan, the eel sauce had a lovely touch of umami and sweetness but did not overpower your tastebuds

EUrWrmHB7xl4zd_47-2X2A.text: Big selection, big portions and really good value. We got the bento boxes for £8.50 each and just about finished them  I got there at 6.30 on a Monday and got a table for two.15 minutes later when my friend arrives she had to make her way through a growing queue.So like anything good in Soho, get there early or be prepared to wait!

k5p6Cir5qQ_4t9kVnq12wg.text: Great pre-theatre dinner. Fresh sushi! The menu is HUGE, but everything has a photo so it's so easy to find something that you'll love. The Tokyo dragon roll was fantastic. So much flavor. Even if you're not a raw fish fan they have plenty of other options! Definitely a great sushi bar!

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom

vF33PR-6CmgRyjUow-nrdw.text: I went into Eat Tokyo on a whim because I was seeing a play nearby and wanted some Japanese. Boy was I impressed! First of all the menu was EXPANSIVE. I mean I've seen big menus at other sushi places but this menu is a binder full of options. The service was ok- just based on the servers who I talked to, the women were very nice and the men were a bit curt.I ordered two inari which were yummy; they came out very quickly. Then I got some vegetable gyoza which were perfect. The bottoms had just the right amount of crunch and the tops were just soft enough. I also enjoyed the sauce they served with it. I then got my vegetable tempura bento box which came out really well. I had a few minor issues with it: the carrot tempura was a bit under cooked and the tofu could have been crisper and/or more flavorful. But otherwise I loved it. The tempura batter was superb! A vsweet woman asked if I wanted any desserts and she sold me on trying two different mochis, one mango and one green tea. They were so good! If I had made them I would have made the outside a little thicker, but that's just my personal preference. Also the green tea mochi had a very strong green tea flavor, which wasn't bad but it definitely was unusual.All in all this place was really quite good. It wasn't perfect (as I mentioned in my notes above), but I would definitely frequent Eat Tokyo if I lived here.

photos.caption: Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Eat Tokyo - London, United Kingdom

DnGhrfOfbjUaWgE_B0a1jQ.text: In an area with so many options, I'm surprised to see this place with four stars - slow, uninterested service, and oversalted, tired food. Tried to stay safe with the beef bento, but miso soup was bland, tofu was dry, salad was old and tired, and beef was drowned in salt. It's worth walking a bit to find somewhere better - don't waste your time or your stomach here.

YHak709Fqbwro8sPiY2L3Q.text: Came in just before last orders last night and was greeted and shown to the bar. Being late, the teriyaki and curry were both gone for the day, but it wasn't really what I was looking for anyway. The menu is large and has pictures so nice and accessible for everybody.I ordered two different types of roll, a spicy tartar roll (fresh chili, salmon, tuna and white fish), and an eel/avocado roll as well as the katsu jyu - breaded pork cutlet and egg sauce on rice. The sushi came quickly and was freshly made (I was sitting at the sushi counter) and I had enough time to eat it before the main dish arrived. The fish seemed very fresh and I enjoyed the crunchy chili inside the roll as well as the standard wasabi and soy. They were well put together and didn't fall apart or seemed squeezed into mush. The Katsu Jyu was huge though, 2 pork cutlets, sauce and rice. I needed to actually move some of the cutlet to the sushi plate in order to enjoy the dish fully and get at the rice. Slightly odd addition of bamboo shoots in addition to the standard onion, but not a bad extra. It could have used a little more sauce though, it seemed a little thin on the amount of rice given.Service was quick and they dealt with a large number of people coming in. They announced last orders and a short while later carried out the threat (the waiter seemed quite happy to announce the closure of the restaurant for the day!)One gripe I have, the doors don't close unless someone really pushes them closed. The seat that I was given at the bar meant that I was constantly in a draft of cold air from the outside that was channeled through this gap. I was close enough to get a chill and far enough away that I would need to leave the bar in order to close it. And even though the door would get closed, the problem would start again as soon as someone else came into this popular restaurant. Try to avoid sitting there!

iZ_6MyJG28l_lLEWwynJqw.text: We came here for dinner with a friend.  We were worried when we saw a line waiting outside of the restaurant before 5pm, and that they won't have a table for 7 of us.  To my amazement the restaurant is actually very big.  We were seated within 10 minutes.  The food selection is huge, and the price is very reasonable.  The wait staff is attentive and friendly.  Highly recommend!

nfkpaRNSibiWR2njQ1EdGA.text: Relatively cheaper meals that taste very home-y and nice. The store is bigger than it looks and gets busy in peak hours so be prepared to wait in a queue. They also have lunch hour deals, which I think is worth checking out!

BS0cbFzZtbXq6L11iW-GDA.text: Brilliant!!!! Through yelp I discovered this place.As soon as I got there We saw a small queue, I was confused at first but after I left I can assure you it was worth the small wait.Extremely fast and kind service and great food. Overall definitely recommend this place if looking for a nice atmosphere and exquisite japonese food.

PtTbly8EF8PYHsXHW-SJFQ.text: Great place to go for very reasonably priced Japanese dishes and sushi! The food is really good, but not the best by any means, but if you're looking for a place that serves a hefty amount of portions, good price, and good taste, this place is for you.

i1QGsnz39KeWWgmGy3-y9Q.text: Huge portions, authentic feel and delicious food; this is a great place for fans of Japanese food.I went there with a big group and while there is a lot of space to accommodate that it is best to book in advance just in case. As soon as we got in and say down the staff, all dressed in traditional kimonos, gave us the the menus and some tap water.I chose one of the bento boxes that came with chicken, salmon,some extra fish pieces, salad, rice and miso soup. Everything was delicious to the point I really can't pick a favourite and for £15 that is costs you really get to eat a lot of food to fill you up.I have been telling everybody about it because I think it's a great place for Japanese food and you should definitely go there! In fact just go book right now, you know you want to. :)
